content: How can I help you today?

I've been struggling to sleep well lately. My mind just won't stop racing at night, and I can't seem to turn it off. There's a lot going on at work, and I'm really worried about losing my job. It feels overwhelming.

That sounds incredibly heavy to deal with—lying awake while your mind is racing can make everything feel even more overwhelming, especially when work pressure is adding to the mix. It's understandable to feel this way when so much is going on. What's been helping you get through these moments so far?

Honestly, I end up just reaching for my phone and scrolling through social media or watching videos. It helps distract me for a bit, but I know it’s not really helpful in the long run—it probably keeps me up even later. I feel stuck in this loop.

It sounds like scrolling through your phone gives you a temporary escape from the worries, even though you're aware it's not helping your sleep situation long-term. Feeling stuck in a cycle like this can be frustrating. What could a good night’s rest mean for you, if things were different?

A good night's rest would mean a lot. I feel like it would help me focus better at work, be more patient with my kids, and just feel less overwhelmed in general. I can't even remember the last time I woke up actually feeling refreshed. Right now, it’s like I’m running on fumes most days.

The thought of waking up refreshed, being focused at work, and feeling more patient with your kids sounds like it holds a lot of meaning for you. It seems like better sleep could really make a difference in how you face your day and handle the things most important to you. What do you think might make moving closer to that a possibility?

I don’t really know where to start. I’ve thought about trying to put my phone away before bed, but the moment I start feeling stressed or my thoughts won’t stop, I just reach for it out of habit. It’s hard to imagine breaking that cycle when my mind feels so out of control.

It can be really tough to break a habit when stress takes over and pulling out your phone has been your go-to for relief. Starting something new often feels challenging, especially when your thoughts are overwhelming. Thinking about where you are now, what would need to change for you to feel ready to try something different?
I think I’d need something else to turn to instead of my phone, but I have no idea what that could be. It’s hard to imagine that anything else would work when my mind is racing like it does.

It's understandable to feel unsure of alternatives, especially when it’s been such a strong habit during stressful moments. It sounds like you're open to the idea of replacing your phone use but aren't certain yet what might really help calm your mind. What types of activities or strategies, even small ones, have ever brought you a sense of calm or relief in the past?

I don't know, honestly. I used to read more, but it feels like I can't concentrate on anything these days. Sometimes listening to music helps, but I haven't really tried it to relax before bed. I guess I just have trouble believing anything will actually work.

It’s hard to believe something could help, especially when it feels like your stress and racing thoughts have such a strong hold. It’s good to hear that listening to music has helped bring some relief in the past, even though you haven’t tried it before bedtime. It sounds like you're open to exploring options, even if there’s some hesitation. What might make it easier to take a small step toward trying something different?

I'd probably need to just commit to trying it for a night or two and see what happens, but it's hard to feel motivated when I'm so tired. Maybe if I had a plan or something simple to follow, it wouldn't feel so overwhelming.

Having a simple plan could make things feel less overwhelming and help you take that first step, even when you're tired. You've already shown thoughtfulness in recognizing what might help and a willingness to try, which shows a lot of strength. Before we explore a plan, is there anything else you’d want to talk through or share about your sleep struggles?
Not really. I think I’ve shared the main stuff that’s been on my mind. I just feel stuck, and I guess I’m hoping things can get a little better.

You’ve shared a lot, and your openness shows just how much you care about making things better, even while feeling stuck. To recap what we’ve talked about, your sleep struggles seem to be linked to stress and those racing thoughts at night, which have led you to use your phone as a distraction. You mentioned that better sleep would help you feel more focused at work, be more patient with your kids, and just feel less overwhelmed overall. You've also expressed interest in exploring small changes, like replacing phone use with music or another calming activity before bed, and the idea of having a simple plan seems helpful to you.

Would it feel okay to shift toward discussing ideas for a plan now?
Yeah, I think that would be alright. Having a plan might give me something to stick to and try, even if it’s just small steps. Let’s do it.

That’s great to hear, and small steps can often make a big difference over time. Let’s work together on creating a plan that feels manageable for you. You mentioned music as something that has helped you feel calm in the past. How might you incorporate that into your bedtime routine as a way to replace scrolling through your phone?

Maybe I could create a playlist of calming music and try playing that instead of reaching for my phone. I could set it up before bed, so it’s ready to go when I start feeling stressed. It might be worth a shot to see if it helps quiet my mind a bit.

That’s a thoughtful idea—having a calming playlist ready beforehand could make it easier to turn to music when stress hits, rather than your phone. It’s a simple step that doesn’t feel overly complicated to manage. How do you feel about adding one more small element to the plan, like setting a specific time to put your phone away and focus on winding down with the playlist?
